posts.cooked:
I know this may be a big ask, but hear me out.

Premise
Meta has a messenger tailored to kids. They have some special features and a few games in there and what not. I think it is very smart for a brand that people know, to offer an app to kids that are likely to convert into life long users. I just wish it was Signal instead of Meta.

Scenario:
I have a kid who is starting to read, and very excited to talk to her friends remotely. But even if I would let her use my phone, the parents on the other side might not be able or want to.

Suggestion

  • An app that can run on a tablet without a sim card
  • Easy interface
  • (Group) calls
  • Video calls
  • Ability to send text (with suggestions) and emoticons
  • Simple games they can play, this would be a nice extra.

You would need to be able to have multiple accounts on the same phone number in case you have more than 1 kid.

Thoughts?

Very unlikely to happen due to COPPA. Signal would have to collect more information from users in order to be able to comply with the law (you have to get verifiable parental consent to allow users under 13).
Ah‚Ä¶ I guess that does complicate things. Kind of ironic though, that the only alternative is pretty much the worst business regarding children‚Äôs online safety.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Just let them use the version that exists. Set up a Google Voice number, register it, set the phone number to be hidden, disable discoverability by phone number, and create a nonsensical username (e.g. generate a random 12 character alphanumeric string with a password manager) for them to give to friends so they can still connect but not be easily messaged by creepy weirdos.

MTGninja:

1 An app that can run on a tablet without a sim card
2 Easy interface
3 (Group) calls
4 Video calls
5 Ability to send text (with suggestions) and emoticons
6 Simple games they can play, this would be a nice extra.

  1. Can already be done on iPads
  2. I don‚Äôt know how to make a chat app any easier to use
  3. Already doable
  4. Already doable
  5. Already doable (suggestions are dependent on the keyboard and not the app)
  6. I don‚Äôt know why this necessarily needs to be in the Signal app when two people can download the same standalone game and play together

It‚Äôs good idea but even if Google Voice would be globally available, that (or an alternative) requires some effort/tech-savyness for all the parents involved to just have an app working. To me, that‚Äôs worth it, but it‚Äôs quite an obstacle for others and I have strong doubts if any of my kids‚Äô friends will have it arranged. Even if I was to offer to do it for them.

I also definitely think that there are ways to make a chat app easier to use for kids, especially if they can‚Äôt read yet. But thats not the priority here.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: Ah yeah. Not doable outside of the U.S. but there are similar services. They shouldn‚Äôt take much effort to set up.

MTGninja:

especially if they can‚Äôt read yet.

Should Children who can‚Äôt read yet really be allowed access to a global communication system? I really don‚Äôt think this is a good idea.

Avitus:

Just let them use the version that exists

Anyone under 13 using the app is violating the ToS.

Avitus:

create a nonsensical username (e.g. generate a random 12 character alphanumeric string with a password manager) for them to give to friends so they can still connect but not be easily messaged by creepy weirdos.

Unfortunately, that is not really any good. All it takes is clicking one random public group link, or being added to the wrong group by one of their friends and suddenly they‚Äôre being inundated with inappropriate content and exposed to all kinds of ‚Äúcreepy weirdos‚Äù with little to no way to stop it. Signal has no protection against being added to spam groups against your will. It‚Äôs not an app for little kids.

Most likely a lot of parents use WhatsApp or iMessage with their kids.
The same can be done with Signal, just make sure their phone number privacy is set to Nobody for both options, see number and find by number. And during registration, set a fake first name only and change it on your phone using Nicknames.
If they have to add friends, make them do it in front of you so you can verify it, using usernames and setting a custom nickname.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm pretty sure that since the only info Signal knows is the phone number, if the parent were to use a phone number they own (which is likely the case anyway) and they are the ones to set up the account for the kid, then everything is legal. isn‚Äôt it?
edit: the ToS still forbids it as far as I understand. but it may be COPPA legal.

At the risk of being considered ignorant, I would still like to ask: what is your specific concern?

With proper parental controls in place, I don‚Äôt see the problem. Adding new friends could be restricted behind a parent‚Äôs password, or you could even limit it to only being able to add a friend that is physically with you. Communication could be limited to sending emoticons, calls could require parental approval before they can connect and it can be limited to how long they can use it. It would be work to approve things for a parent, but I‚Äôm talking about 4-7 year olds. A parent should be hands on with them anyway.

I think it would be great for kids to keep up the relationships to their friends, especially if they are more remote. And it is a good way to develop their social skills if they are ready for it.

Can it be abused? Probably, but if it‚Äôs build right, it would require a parent who is very negligent. Then pretty much everything in the world is a hazard to kids. With only Meta (Facebook‚Ä¶) offering a version tailored to kids, I think a kids Signal version would surely be a better and much safer option.

if the parent were to use a phone number they own ‚Ä¶

Can you have more than 1 Signal account per phone number?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: no, but you can have more than one phone number. landlines count.
I don‚Äôt think everyone has an additional number, but even if that was the case, we would still have an unrestricted Signal. I think some parental controls as I mentioned above, would be favorable.
Look into Deltachat (email). You would be able to whitelist and blacklist using filters from your email provider.

I think this may be somewhat of a duplicate request:

Parental feature Feature Requests
I would love to see a parental pass code for certain features such as adding contacts, receiving videos and photos, and using GIF‚Äôs to make Signal kid-friendly!

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: kinda, though they‚Äôre asking for different specific features.

posts.name: Salim B
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôd be intersted too in a parent/kids feature.

Like creating a dedicated account to a child, or even a person with mental disabiliy, and attaching it to a parent / main account.

The control I would like to have over kids / managed accounts are :

  • enable / disable white listing of accounts to send message to and receive message from
  • could be black listing too (as an alternative option), but not as important as zwhite listing.
  • enable / disable ability to add new contacts in managed account.
  • ability to block settings so managed account can‚Äôt override the chosen settings.

And I dont intend to have control over message content, or have a overview on it. I just dont want my kids to receive a random crypto or porn span message as it happens on Signal sometimes (and on Instagram or WhatsApp also‚Ä¶), or to be in contact with people I cant trust.

I see this as a way to onboard some more people to messaging capability (my kids love to receive pictures from their grand mother) possibly persons we should keep safe. And also as a way teach how they can do it safely by themselves when groing up (disabling protection over time, giving them their privacy without looking at their messages).
Sounds like https://bark.us

Kids in elementary school don‚Äôt need a smartphone. They may want one, but they really don‚Äôt need one. There‚Äôs a never-ending debate going on, and rightfully so, whether they should be allowed to even use one or to have their own phones at this age.

It‚Äôs different with tablet computers and the schooling system I guess. The times they are a changin‚Äô ‚Ä¶

Why do kids need group and video calls anyway? A dedicated Signal app for kids or Signal running in ‚Äúkids mode‚Äù IMO should be stripped of key features (like video chat, groups and group calls) that could be abused / wrongly used and cause (psychological or physical) harm. Kids are no saints and there‚Äôs a lot of harm being done behind the scenes, when parents aren‚Äôt looking‚Ä¶ . God knows how many grown ups have to deal with psychological disorders that are rooted in childhood.

But I do like the ‚Äúeasy interface‚Äù and ‚Äúsimple games‚Äù ideas.
